snippet.textDisplay: Takes notes 60-minutes, THIS is how you do an interview. Pat hit her hard with questions that were rough, but worded very fairly. He conducted himself with very friendly and inviting body language and didn't make her feel alienated. Fantastic work, Pat. Keep it up.
snippet.textOriginal: Takes notes 60-minutes, *THIS* is how you do an interview. Pat hit her hard with questions that were rough, but worded very fairly. He conducted himself with very friendly and inviting body language and didn't make her feel alienated. Fantastic work, Pat. Keep it up.

snippet.textDisplay:
"videos that depict violence get demonitized, and that's fine."

No, it's not. You can't report on violence than.

Mainstream media shows an attack, they stay monetized.

Anyone else, they lose monetization.

snippet.textDisplay:
MatPat: "Can we have the rules on demonetization?" (You know, so we don't get demonetized for random things)
Susan: "Videos are complicated...."

snippet.textDisplay:
Good interview, I would want you to ask about a hard rating system similar to the ratings for TV programs where creators set their own preferred age range and are slapped for violating the guidelines for their rating.
With a hard rating system, all questions of political leanings and graphic content would be effectively baked into the cake. Advertisers would be able to opt into whichever rating system best suit their interests and YouTube can separate themselves from accusations of unfairness.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: The board for YouTube needs to fire this woman and get someone who isn't a corporate shill in there. If YT can't be profitable without traditional media wh0ring, then it sounds like there is no home for many communities on YT anymore, and we need to leave. Problem is, there is next to no competition for YT. Bitchute and the like are infinitesimal comparatively. It's not a very lucrative business the way YT runs it. Who knows? Maybe someone will discover the secret. Maybe there just needs to be more websites dedicated to specific types of video content, like Twitch for gaming.
snippet.textOriginal: The board for YouTube needs to fire this woman and get someone who isn't a corporate shill in there. snippet.textDisplay:
My question for her would be "Why doesn't youtube support xbox gamers?" They need to upgrade their xbox app to allow us to stream to youtube and our channels from our consoles.


As it is, the only way to do it natively from the console is to stream to twitch and them export the archive to youtube. You can't even export from Mixer to Youtube, much less use the youtube app to do it directly.
snippet.textOriginal:
My question for her would be "Why doesn't youtube support xbox gamers?" They need to upgrade their xbox app to allow us to stream to youtube and our channels from our consoles.


As it is, the only way to do it natively from the console is to stream to twitch and them export the archive to youtube. You can't even export from Mixer to Youtube, much less use the youtube app to do it directly.

snippet.textDisplay:
Good interview. It's a shame that she spends most of the time dodging the question and simultaneously assuring you that 'they care'.
You can only be so sympathetic knowing that she has to stay within the distance of a lawyer, at some point there has to be actual honesty involved and less 'brand management'.

The fact is that Youtube refuses to take a stand against advertiser demands and instead of letting them go directly to the channels for deals, they insist on their learning algorithms to sort it out.
Their new "harassment policy" is laughable. We all know that harassment isn't what is actually happening out there, it's people who can't deal with the attention they get, when they say something stupid and/or wrong. At the same time the same people love saying 'freedom of speech doesn't mean freedom from consequence'. Apparently not for them?

Whatever, youtube is a trash platform and it's only getting worse from here.
snippet.textOriginal:
Good interview. It's a shame that she spends most of the time dodging the question and simultaneously assuring you that 'they care'. 
You can only be so sympathetic knowing that she has to stay within the distance of a lawyer, at some point there has to be actual honesty involved and less 'brand management'. 

The fact is that Youtube refuses to take a stand against advertiser demands and instead of letting them go directly to the channels for deals, they insist on their learning algorithms to sort it out.
Their new "harassment policy" is laughable. We all know that harassment isn't what is actually happening out there, it's people who can't deal with the attention they get, when they say something stupid and/or wrong. At the same time the same people love saying 'freedom of speech doesn't mean freedom from consequence'. Apparently not for them?

Whatever, youtube is a trash platform and it's only getting worse from here.

snippet.textDisplay:
I was really expecting you to ask about the burden of proof on claimants of youtube video's and redirecting the monitization of those videos based on just a claim made and nothing else. Why is the burden of proof on the content creator and NOT the claimant? Or about takedowns of videos critical of games by the companies that make them due to "copyrighted content"... why fair use not recognized or enforced on the platform.


I gotta say your questions really just come off as: "Do you care about us?" "Yes" "Are you slanting the system against us?" "No". Your questions felt really weak.

snippet.textDisplay:
Why can't we just get an overhaul of youtube's advertising system?
I know many advertisers are afraid to support political videos and such, but something needs to change.
It would be nice if advertisers could select specific channels or groups of channels to monitize on, as well as in the reverse that channels could request specific advertisers or groups of advertisers. Whichever party, advertiser or content creator, sends the request, the other party must accept or deny the request.

Let the content creators and advertisers decide and cut the middleman (youtube) out. Yes of course youtube gets the money first and it is then distrubuted to the content creators, but this way everyone wins. Advertisers get more widespread and specific viewership, content creators receive more monitization from companies they support, and viewers get ads directed toward their interests relevant to the channels. More monitized channels means more motivation to create content, which means more viewers.

I've seen so many large and small channels disappear or shrink because of lack of monitization and I feel like everyone is losing here. :/

As far as the new policies regarding content directed toward children is concerned, youtube is also being really dumb there too. Youtube is a 13+ website as is the majority of the internet. If someone under 13 sees content they shouldn't, it isn't youtube's responsibility, it is the user and their parent's responsibility. Stop marketing videos and content toward children. If people want to make child-friendly content or videos directed toward children, fine, but there is no reason for youtube to take responsibility or be held accountable when a kid sees something they shouldn't. By taking that stance they're screwing their entire platform over.

Let the content creators and advertisers decide and cut the middleman (youtube) out. Yes of course youtube gets the money first and it is then distrubuted to the content creators, but this way everyone wins. Advertisers get more widespread and specific viewership, content creators receive more monitization from companies they support, and viewers get ads directed toward their interests relevant to the channels. By taking that stance they're screwing their entire platform over.

snippet.textDisplay:
Idk why it's so hard for YouTube to see what will make this platform successful. It's like they're bumbling around in the dark, focusing on company wide stats and bending over for advertisement revenue. That's how you end up where YouTube is at. Mainstream media smears this website and its creators, they've allowed advertisers to control the success and fate of the website, and their own creators don't trust them at best, and hate them at worst.

If YouTube wants to succeed, all it has to do is put their full weight into supporting and empowering it's creators. EVERYTHING YouTube does should make life better for the creators. They need to create some line of communication between YouTube and their creators. Instead of getting a video taken down with no explanation, for example. I guarantee that if they put their creators first, every time, YouTube will only grow and flourish. Instead, YouTube routinely shits all over the people who actually make them money.
snippet.textOriginal:

If YouTube wants to succeed, all it has to do is put their full weight into supporting and empowering it's creators. EVERYTHING YouTube does should make life better for the creators. They need to create some line of communication between YouTube and their creators. Instead of getting a video taken down with no explanation, for example. I guarantee that if they put their creators first, every time, YouTube will only grow and flourish. Instead, YouTube routinely shits all over the people who actually make them money.

snippet.textDisplay:
This was great! Matpat, you are a wonderful interviewer. I wouldn't be surprised if somebody asks you to do more of these sometime. With that said, she played you pretty well. She learned the way you wanted your questions answered and worded everything very carefully to work around that. Your first few questions and your demeanor caught her by surprise and you had her on the defensive, but by the end it was obvious she was in control. It became clear very fast why she's a CEO.



That's probably one of the most fascinating interviews I've ever watched from an interpersonal standpoint. You both did extremely well in your respective roles. Thank you very much for making that happen.


Edit: grammar

snippet.textDisplay:
I know that no one might read this but I can hope that maybe MatPat reviews the comments on this video specifically.

I LOVE your videos! I can't stress enough how much I respect what you do and feel like you truly have the well-being of content creators and the audience at heart and how interesting your videos are.

With that said, I do feel like you could have handled this interview a bit better. From the outset it seemed like you were asking the "tough questions" but there were several ways those questions could have been improved as well as ways you could have read your interviewee that would have made for significantly fewer awkward interactions. For example, your first "tough" question, I'll paraphrase of course, came across to me like "Gamers feel like second class citizens. Is this feeling valid?" A better way to phrase it would probably have been something like "Sometimes it feels like Gamers are second class citizens on your platform due to X. Has this feeling been expressed to YouTube and if so, what ways has/is YouTube addressing these issues?"

Most of your questions felt like attacks when they didn't have to. That's the main point of that criticism. The second criticism I'd raise is the kind of poorly placed jokes between the questions. They honestly weren't needed and they caused, I feel, more animosity and had some argumentative and childish qualities to them. Now I understand that most of them were intended as jokes like the one about watching the ticking clock. Maybe this is my own interpretation but I get the feeling that Susan has been in the corporate world for so long that she was treating this like a corporate event. So she didn't have her playful, jokey hat on which made her a bit more defensive, especially with the ways you were asking some of the questions. Even the ones that came across as jokes felt almost half serious. That's what caused a lot of the tension that I would hope you felt at the time.

Again, this is not meant as some kind of scathing commentary but this really seemed like an opportunity to build a rapport between YouTube and gaming creators but you took it as more of an opportunity to hit her with your "tough journalistic questions." Hopefully some of this resonates with you, MatPat 😊
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: I think it's really good that YouTube is looking into separating real and video game violence in terms of monetization; hopefully something like that will help games like Mortal Kombat and such to be able to solidly get back on the platform!
snippet.textOriginal: I think it's really good that YouTube is looking into separating real and video game violence in terms of monetization; hopefully something like that will help games like Mortal Kombat and such to be able to solidly get back on the platform!
